The Pearl River School District is happy to support a local initiative in mass producing protective face shields for doctors and nurses in the region.
Kevin Garrison, Evans Park parent contacted us and asked if we could lend our support to his brother, Vinny Garrison, a Nanuet technology teacher and uncle to three Pearl River students, one of the leaders of this effort. Using about a dozen 3D printers in his garage, Mr. Garrison has printed over 500 of these shields. Four 3D printers from Pearl River High School, Evans Park and Franklin Avenue Elementary Schools are now part of this effort that is bringing much needed personal protective equipment to healthcare workers battling COVID-19.

Pearl River High School's Model United Nations club hosted their first interschool conference at PRHS on Saturday. Students from Brewester, Nanuet, and Tappan Zee participated in two exciting committees - A Crisis Committee on the Millionaire DoomsDay Plan and a General Assembly committee on the United Nations Development Programme debating the Somali Flood Crisis.

The keynote speaker for the event was Ms. Hawa Taylor-Kamara Diallo the Chief of the Civil Society Unit within the Civil Society and Advocacy Section of the Department of Global Communications of the United Nations.

Pearl River students started their work in putting this program together in September. They did a great job! Thank you to the students and club advisor, Christina Hohner.

post_text: Last week we honored Dr. Arlene Clinkscale at Lincoln Ave. School. Dr. Clinkscale started her NY educational career in 1960 when she was hired to teach first grade at Lincoln Ave. She was the 1st African American teacher in Pearl River. She later became the 1st African American female principal in Rockland County while in the East Ramapo School District, and then the 1st African-American female superintendent in NY in the Nyack School District. It was a beautiful tribute for a wonderful educator! We thank everyone who attended, including Orangetown Supervisor, Teresa Kenny, OPD Chief Butterworth and Frances Pratt, Nyack NAACP President.

post_text: The Pearl River School District received a $3000 grant from the Coalition to Support Grieving Students. Steven Crabbe, PRHS Alumnus, delivered a presentation and presented resources at the start of the school year to district school psychologists, special education teachers and the #PRSELFIE Committee. These resources help teachers, counselors, and all school personnel to support students who have experienced the death of a parent, sibling, or other beloved person. As a result, we have been awarded a Grief-Sensitive Schools Initiative grant. The grant funds will be used to purchase curriculum materials and picture books that will support our social emotional learning objectives. Thank you to Mr. Crabbe and the Coalition for their support!

post_text: Congratulations to this year's PRMS 7th grade DARE graduates. This program is another excellent example of the partnership between families, our school district, the police department and the town that benefits our students. Thank you to the Orangetown Board for their support of the program, OPD and DARE instructors, Officer Muckelland and Officer Lopez, and the MS administration and faculty, particularly the 7th grade science teachers, who welcomed the officers into their classes. This was the last DARE graduation for Chief Nulty who retired at the end of April. We thank him for his many years of service and leadership. We also congratulate our new Chief of Police, Donald Butterworth. We are confident that our partnership will continue to benefit the students and our school community under his leadership.

post_text: The Pearl River High School small choirs traveled on Friday, May 3rd, to Palmyra, PA to participate in the Music In The Parks Competition. The Jazz Choir, Modulators, Women’s Glee Club, and Pirate Pearls each performed 2 songs and were scored with other schools performing groups from NY, PA, NJ, and Delaware. Each of the groups received first place in their division. In addition, the Pirate Pearls received the highest score overall, and Annemarie Bowler received an outstanding soloist award. Congratulations to all our vocalists and music teacher, Shereen Way!

post_text: Recently, the PRHS Youth & Government club attended the statewide conference in Albany where student legislators Alanah Fitzgerald and Colleen Griffin-Turk presented their bill to require voters to present photo ID at polling stations before voting, which not only successfully passed, but was chosen out of over 200 bills to be the basis of next year’s conference topic. This was a hard earned achievement and great honor! Pearl River is the only club in three counties that brought Judicial members to the state conference. Teige Beaudry successfully argued his case to a panel of Justices, one of whom was Liam Fitzpatrick. Ciara Timoney and Marissa Anselmi were members of the Press reporting not only on the happenings of the conference, but also created insightful interviews of attendees. Congratulations to the students and club advisor, Maureen Carroll!
